The Particular Integral

Given a second order ODE \[ a{\mathrm{d}^2y\over \mathrm{d}x^2}+b{\mathrm{d}y\over \mathrm{d}x}+c\ y=f(x),\]

a particular integral is any function, \(y_\text{p}(x)\), which satisfies the ODE. That is, any function which when substituted into the left-hand side, results in the expression on the right-hand side.

Example

Show that \( y = -\dfrac{1}{4}e^{2x}\) is a particular integral of \[ \dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2} - \dfrac{dy}{dx} - 6y = e^{2x} \]

Solution

Starting with \( y = -\dfrac{1}{4}e^{2x}\) we find \[ \dfrac{dy}{dx} = - \dfrac{1}{2}e^{2x}, \qquad \dfrac{d^2y}{dx^2} =-e^{2x} \]

Substitution into the ODE yields \[ - e^{2x} - (- \dfrac{1}{2}e^{2x}) - 6 (- \dfrac{1}{2}e^{2x})\]

which simplifies to \(e^{2x},\) the same as the right-hand side.

Therefore \( y = -\dfrac{1}{4}e^{2x}\) is a particular integral and we write (attaching a subscript p):

\( y_{p}(x) = -\dfrac{1}{4}e^{2x}.\)

A particular integral is any solution of a differential equation.
